memoryVerse: "Who is going to harm you if you are eager to do good? But even if you should suffer for what is right, you are blessed." – 1 Peter 3:13-14

one.title: FIRST DAY: Read the notes and the references.

questions.questionText: 1. Use this space to record how you have seen God's activity during the week. (How has He provided, answered, comforted, reconciled, guided, etc.?)
2. What from the notes, lecture, group sharing or personal study impacted you most in the past week?

two.title:
SECOND DAY: Read Acts 13:1-14a.
The Holy Spirit sent out Barnabas and Saul.

questions.questionText: 3. a. Describe the events that led to Paul and Barnabas's appearance before the proconsul.
3. b. Compare and contrast the response to the Word by Elymas and the proconsul.
4. a. What do you learn from Paul and Barnabas's experience?
4. b. What might God be setting you apart to do? What inspires or challenges you about this?

three.title:
THIRD DAY: Read Acts 13:14b-41.
Paul continued the work at Pisidian Antioch.

questions.questionText: 5. Paul's sermon has three sections. What key points and verses in the first part of the sermon (13:16-25) reveal: § God's choice of Israel and His goodness to them? § the promised Messiah?
6. What is revealed about Jesus and His work on our behalf in the second part of the sermon (13:26-37)?
7. What is the warning and promise that applies to everyone in the third part of the sermon (13:38-41)? What is your response?

four.title:
FOURTH DAY: Read Acts 13:42-52.
Paul and Barnabas faced persecution in their return to the synagogue.

questions.questionText: 8. What was the cause of hostility toward Paul and Barnabas? How did they respond?
9. Paul and Barnabas experienced disgrace and joys at Pisidian Antioch. What does this teach you about God and serving Him?
10. What current obstacles do you face in your work for the Lord? How are you responding?

five.title:
FIFTH DAY: Read Acts 14.
Paul and Barnabas continued to witness despite severe persecution.

questions.questionText: 11. From this passage, what happens when the Word of God is effectively preached?
12. What is most troubling about the people's response in Lystra? How are people tempted to worship the messenger today?
13. What blessings have you seen through your sharing and living out the gospel? What consequences have you experienced?
14. What was your biggest takeaway from your personal study of this week's lesson?
15. Passage Discovery (homiletics, word study, etc.) for group and administrative leaders: Acts 13-14
